ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a great class! Even if you are not that interested in Canada, Quebec is a great starting point for a lot of interesting discussions that apply to many other things.

This class is a nice and soft introduction to the history major. The actual seminars usually run long, but are, for the most part, actively fun. The class is highly interactive and runs like a well-informed conversation between friends, rather than a lecture structure. And the reading is not actually as threatening as it looks on the syllabus. I would definitely recommend this class to someone who thinks they might be interested in trying out History as a discipline, or to somebody looking for a welcoming, inclusive seminar.
Take it if you need an easy seminar and don't mind being bored often and not having a lot of structure.
This is a pretty easy history credit if you're looking for one. You will probably be bored a lot and I didn't really learn anything.
Yes, absolutely. The course in fun and the subject is one that we are not really taught. I learned a lot about Canada, of which I knew almost nothing before.
I would definitely recommend HIST 168J. The readings are very worthwhile, seminar is enjoyable, and Professor Gitlin is both very knowledgeable and a lot of fun.
A must take. Great way to learn a forgotten history

TAKE THIS CLASS! I knew nothing about Quebec and very little about Canadian history before taking it. Turns out it's absolutely fascinating. Professor Gitlin is amazing and truly cares about his students; strongly consider taking both Quebec and Yale and America if you can. This is one of the few classes I've taken at Yale in which I've made friends. Prof. G makes sure that people know each other, and he creates a fun, collaborative learning environment. The work isn't bad (3 page paper, group presentation, 15 page research paper). You'll learn a lot and have a great time. Absolutely a win-win.

This is a fun history seminar about an interesting topic. There is a lot of reading, but you actually don't need to do most of it. The main assignments are a short 3 page paper and a longer term paper. Take it for relaxed Tuesday afternoons.

A not particularly rigorous history seminar with a passionate, interesting, committed, and funny. However, don't expect a rigorous course from which you exit knowing everything there is to know. The rigor is low but the end-product is only a broad strokes understanding of the history.Significant but not excessive reading with minimized pressure to do it.Midterm paper 3 pgsFinal research paper 15-20 pgsGood class for non-history majors too
